comments: Number of walks of length 4 between any two distinct vertices of the complete graph K_{n+1} (n >= 1). Example: a(2) = 5 because in the complete graph ABC we have the following walks of length 4 between A and B: ABACB, ABCAB, ACACB,ACBAB and ACBCB. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 01 20041/a(n), for n>=2, is in base n given by 0.repeat(0,0,1,1), due to (1/n^3 + 1/n^4)*(1/(1 - 1/n^4)) = 1/((n-1)*(n^2+1)). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jun 20 2014For n>3, a(n) is 1220 in base n-1. - _Bruno Berselli_, Jan 26 2016
links: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
formula: a(n) = round[n^4/(n+1)] for n > 2 = A062160(n, 4).G.f.: (4x-1)(1+x^2)/(1-x)^4 (for the signed sequence). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 01 2004a(n) = floor(n^5/(n^2+n)), n > 0. - _Gary Detlefs_, May 27 2010a(n) = -A053698(-n). [_Bruno Berselli_, Jan 26 2016]
maple: [seq(n^3-n^2+n-1,n=0..49)]; # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 29 2006a:=n->sum(1+sum(n, k=1..n), k=2..n):seq(a(n), n=0...43); # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Aug 24 2008
mathematica: Table[n^3 - n^2 + n - 1, {n, 0, 49}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Apr 30 2014 *)
author: _Henry Bottomley_, Jun 08 2001
